description.et: Kursuse käigus loetakse viit Martin Heideggeri hilisesse loominguperioodi kuuluvat esseed, pühendades igale neist kaks seminarikohtumist. Konkreetsed tekstid on valitud lähtudes sellest, et neis kõigis tegeletakse tähenduse taasavastamisega nihilismi ja modernsuse kontekstis. Vaadeldavates esseedes esitab Heidegger väljakutse mõnedele kõige olulisematele aluseeldustele, mis puudutavad inimkogemust ja inimese rolli tänapäeva maailmas.

objectives.en: The aim is to familiarise students with key concepts of Heidegger's later thought. Through the course, participants will become acquainted with certain core ideas throughout Heidegger's philosophy with the aim of cultivating their own thinking in relationship to their own life/existence and scholarly/academic interests.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on tutvustada üliõpilastele Martin Heideggeri hilisema perioodi filosoofia võtmekontseptsioone. Kursuse jooksul tutvutakse Heideggeri filosoofiat läbivate ideedega, mille mõju võiks osalejad ergutada sügavamalt järele mõtlema oma elu/olemise ja teaduslike/akadeemiliste huvide üle.

objectives.en: As his later thought is generally considered more accessible than his magnum opus "Being & Time," studying the later Heidegger can also serve as a primer for studying his earlier work, including "Being & Time."
objectives.et: Kuna Heideggeri hilisemaid kirjutisi võib pidada ligipääsetavamaks kui  tema peateost "Olemine ja aeg", annab hilise Heideggeri lugemine hea aluse lähenemiseks tema varasematele töödele sh teosele "Olemine ja aeg".

notes.et:
* Description of Content
We will read five essays of Heidegger's later writings, spending two classes on each essay. These essays have been selected because they all deal with the rediscovery of meaning within the context of nihilism and modernity. In these essays, Heidegger challenges some of our most basic assumptions concerning our human experience and where we stand in the world today. 

These essays deal with: 
*	the history of Western philosophy
*	the nature of truth
*	nihilism
*	metaphysics
*	meaning-making
*	destiny
*	modern crises
*	technology
*	poetry contrasted with logic and science
*	the role of philosophy

* Class Structure
During each seminar, we will begin with questions students may have and then proceed to review the homework questions (in pairs and as a group). The remainder of the seminar will be devoted to reading passages of the text aloud and interpreting/discussing them. With two classes per essay, we can proceed at a speed that will facilitate increased depth of discussion and comprehension of the materials.

independent_work.et:
Preparing for the seminars.
Assignments: Students will write 300-500 words in answer to 2-3 questions per week on Moodle related to the reading and the themes discussed in class. For the first seminar dealing with a specific essay, the questions will be oriented towards facilitating an understanding of the core concepts. Questions for the second seminar of that essay will focus on students relating themes in the essay to the supplemental reading materials. The aim with all of the questions is to engage students with the material in a way that requires them to show that they have done the reading and thought about its core contents but that also facilitates them applying the ideas to some area of life or thought that is important and personal to them.

If two classes are missed OR if two assignments are missed OR if one class and one assignment are missed, the student will need to write a one-page reflection on a topic to be determined, in order to pass. If a student misses more than two classes/assignments/a mixture of both, barring a medical emergency, getting credit for the course will not be possible.

resources.mandatory_materials:
The five essays:

1. On the Essence of Truth -- What is truth? What makes truth true? "Essence" usually brings to mind something enduring, permanent, ultimate -- as does "truth." This essay explores such questions and their relationship to the very roots of our existence.

2. The Thing -- What is a thing? Are things merely objects? What is the difference between entities and things? As Heidegger asks, what, ultimately, can we say about the thinghood of a thing? The essays present a striking image of the interconnectedness present in the human experience and the nature of existence.

3. Building, Dwelling, Thinking -- A traditional saying runs: "Home is where the heart is." When we think of dwelling, we think of home and the life we have built. But we also dwell upon various matters through thinking. Heidegger explores the link between these three dimensions of the human experience in the context of the postwar landscape, where homelessness, empty dwellings, and empty thoughts are on the rise.

4. The Question Concerning Technology -- What is the essence of modern technology? How does modern technology differ from simpler forms of technology, say, in the case of a hydroelectric plant versus a windmill? What of the Greek origin of the word techne? Here, Heidegger beckons us to join him in contemplating our destiny in relation to these questions and more.

5. Conversation Between a Young Man and an Old Man -- In the bleak environment of a prisoners of war camp, a young man finds healing from out of the mysterious vastness of the forest that borders the camp and proceeds to share his insights with an older man. Their dialogue quickly becomes a quest for Being -- a navigation of nihilism

These essays will be supplemented with selections from the Cambridge Heidegger Lexicon where relevant and from other sources (i.e., Nietzsche, Aristotle, Plato, etc.-- but only short pieces or summaries of relevant concepts).
